tossups.question: These structures are overproduced in patients with ATIII ("a-t-3") deficiency. In some cases, the improper migration of these structures can be prevented with an IVC filter. The breakdown of these structures can produce D-dimers. The drug alteplase, a synthetic form of TPA, is typically used to break down these structures, whose formation can be inhibited by apixaban. These structures may form via either the (*) "extrinsic" or "intrinsic" pathway, which use over 10 different numbered "factors". In the synthesis of these structures, the enzyme thrombin converts fibrinogen to fibrin, which is then cross-linked to form a solid mesh. Aggregation of platelets causes the formation of, for 10 points, what structures which form in response to blood vessel injury?

Sol LeWitt included 10 peep holes, each with a picture of a nude woman, in a conceptual work titled after this artist "II" ("two"). Francis Bacon, who kept dozens of deteriorated reproductions of this artist's photos in his studio, showed a woman emptying a bowl of water in a painting titled "after" this artist. To create one collection, this artist set up 24 cameras, each with a shutter speed up to 1/1000 ("one-thousandth") of a second, along a track. Photos from this artist's collection The (*) Human Figure in Motion inspired Duchamp's Nude Descending a Staircase No. 2. For Leland Stanford, this artist took photographs of Occident to show that horses lift all four feet off the ground during their gallops. For 10 points, what photographer invented the zoopraxiscope, an early device to display moving images?

A plateau in this country with many flowers, including 45 species of ground orchids, some of which were threatened by heavy gathering as food, is locally called the Garden of God and is in tropical Africa's only botanical reserve; that's the Kitulo Plateau. The Hyena Project studies spotted hyenas in a crater in this country that's densely populated by large mammals and is the largest intact caldera. In this country, the "Four Year War" between the (*) Kahama and Kasakela shocked Jane Goodall during her observation of chimpanzees in Gombe. This country's Ngorongoro Conservation Area sees the start of a yearly Great Migration, which circles around a region split between it and its northern neighbor, Kenya. For 10 points, name this country that has Serengeti National Park and Mount Kilimanjaro.
tossups.answer: United Republic of Tanzania [or Jamhuri ya Muungano wa Tanzania; or al-Jumhuriyah al-Muttahidah as Tanzania]
tossups.answer_formatted: United Republic of Tanzania [or Jamhuri ya Muungano wa Tanzania; or al-Jumhuriyah al-Muttahidah as Tanzania]

bonuses.leadin: Asher Nahor coined a colloquial Israeli word that meant getting swayed in a nationalistic fervor out of this play's title. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this play that was intended as a satire of French behavior under German occupation. The green skin of the title creatures were meant to represent the green uniforms of the Iron Guard and Orpo.

This character is the only one in Rhinoceros that never says, "Well, of all things!" This character is scolded at a cafe by his friend Jean for tardiness in Act I before a rhinoceros starts rampaging.
Rhinoceros is a play by this Romanian playwright who also wrote of the Smiths and Martins in The Bald Soprano.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about Glenn Loury, the first tenured black economist at Harvard:
parts: With linguist John McWhorter, Loury co-founded the 1776 project, which advocates an alternate narrative to this NYT series spearheaded by Nikole Hannah-Jones.

Loury's "dynamic theory" of racial income differences focuses on disparities in this concept between black and non-black communities. Gary Becker popularized this concept, which aggregates education, networks, and technical skills into one factor.
With Harvard president Derek Bok, Loury co-wrote this 1998 book on the "long-term consequences" of the use of race in college admissions.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about various Samuel Taylors:
answers: shorthand systems [accept tachygraphy or brachygraphy systems]
parts: The stenographer Samuel Taylor developed the first one of these systems for the English language which consisted of 19 symbols. They are often used by courtroom clerks to quickly transcribe conversations.
British composer Samuel Coleridge-Taylor is best known for this trilogy of cantatas based on an American poem; its first entry contains the song "Onaway! Awake, beloved!" for tenor and orchestra.
In this long, unfinished ballad by Samuel Taylor Coleridge, the title character goes to pray at an oak tree, where she finds the enchantress Lady Geraldine.

bonuses.leadin: A member of this sect legendarily drowned at sea after sharing one of its secrets, either the dodecahedron or irrational numbers. For 10 points each:
answers: pentagram [accept five-pointed star; prompt on just star; do not accept or prompt on "pentacle"; do not accept or prompt on "pentagon"]
parts: Name this sect that revered mathematics and music, claiming that "all is number". Their belief in metempsychosis caused them to be vegetarian.
The Pythagorean greeting hygieia was often written around this shape that they used as a secret sign because it contains the golden ratio.

Pythagoreans were devoted to this god of mathematics and music said to have given Pythagoras mystical powers. The problem of doubling the cube came from an instruction to double a cubic altar of this god to stop a plague.
answers_formatted: pentagram [accept five-pointed star; prompt on just star; do not accept or prompt on "pentacle"; do not accept or prompt on "pentagon"]
